Article Title: China’s largest contract chipmaker warns of fears about laptop, consumer electronics and car companies, says: Everyone is hesitant to ...
Article Text:

What is causing the memory chip shortage





CEO of China’s largest contract chipmaker, Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC), has a warning. In an earnings call recently, Zhao Haijun, CEO of Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp, said that fears of a memory chip shortage were prompting its customers to hold back orders for other types of chips used in their products. SMIC is China’s largest contract chipmaker. This warning comes as a growing number of chipmakers and industry analysts are warning that a global memory chip shortage could hit consumer electronics and automotive companies next year, as manufacturers shift production toward high-margin components powering the artificial intelligence surge, CNBC reported.“Everyone is hesitant to place too many orders or ship too much in the first quarter of next year because they don’t know how many mobile phones, cars, or other products [the memory chip industry] can supply,” Zhao said, according to a Google translation cited in the report.Analysts told CNBC the bottleneck stems from chipmakers prioritizing advanced memory—especially High-Bandwidth Memory (HBM)—used in AI computing. AI servers, largely powered by processors from Nvidia, depend heavily on HBM, which has become a lucrative focus for suppliers such as SK Hynix and Micron.“The AI build-out is absolutely eating up a lot of the available chip supply, and 2026 looks to be far bigger than this year in terms of overall demand,” Dan Nystedt, vice president of research at TriOrient, told CNBC.AI customers are willing to pay steep prices for premium memory, he said, leaving fewer resources for cheaper chips used in PCs, smartphones, and vehicles. “It could be very bad for PCs, laptops, consumer electronics and automotive, which depend on cheap memory chips. ”Adding to the pressure, the memory industry suffered significant downturns in 2023 and early 2024, leading to under-investment. While companies are now expanding capacity, analysts say new supply will take time to come online.Prices are already rising. Reuters reported last week that Samsung Electronics increased prices for select memory chips by up to 60% compared with September. Samsung did not immediately comment.“With memory prices rising and availability shrinking, concerns about production bottlenecks are gaining traction,” M.S. Hwang, research director at Counterpoint Research, told CNBC. He said supply tightness was already affecting low-end smartphones and set-top boxes and warned that the risk “could broaden.” China, he added, is “feeling the pinch more acutely” due to its reliance on low-cost devices, though the issue is global.Consumers may ultimately bear the cost. Market research firm TrendForce said that the memory sector has entered a “robust upward pricing cycle,” which could force brands to raise retail prices for smartphones, notebooks, and other consumer devices.
Article Summary: CEO of China’s largest contract chipmaker, Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC), has a warning. In an earnings call recently, Zhao Haijun said that fears of a memory chip shortage were prompting its customers to hold back orders for other types of chips used in their products.

Article Title: Google, Facebook parent Meta’s Red Sea Cables facing delay: What is making deployment ‘dangerous’
Article Text:
Missile attacks and increasing cost







Major subsea internet cable projects backed by tech giants Google and Meta Platforms are facing deployment delays in the Red Sea, as report has said, noting that heightened political tensions and security threats have made the crucial route dangerous for commercial vessel operations. The delays affect key global infrastructure intended to supply high-speed internet to Africa and Asia, throttling connectivity for these regions.According to a report by Bloomberg, Meta Platforms’ ambitious 45,000-kilometre 2Africa cable system, planned since 2020 to loop around the African continent, remains unfinished in its southern Red Sea segment five years later.A Meta spokesperson, leading the consortium developing the cable, attributed the lack of progress to a “range of operational factors, regulatory concerns, and geopolitical risk.” Meta's spokesperson has also noted that the company is involved in about 24 global projects and believes the best way to manage risks is to diversify connectivity routes.Similarly, a spokesperson for Google said that progress on its own Google-backed Blue-Raman cable has also been delayed in the region, without providing further specifics.The Red Sea is the historically most direct and cost-effective route for fiber-optic internet arteries, which carry over 95% of global internet traffic, the report says, adding that the construction is complicated by its status as a conflict zone.The primary factor making deployment “dangerous” is the repeated missile attacks over the past two years in the channel by Houthis, the report notes. These attacks have forced commercial cargo ships onto lengthy detours and severely disrupted the work of specialised vessels required to lay and repair the vital subsea cables.To mitigate the escalating risks, telecom and tech companies are now actively exploring alternative overland routes through countries like Bahrain and Saudi Arabia to bypass the Red Sea entirely, the report noted.These paths, once deemed too costly and indirect, are becoming increasingly viable options in light of the Red Sea's mounting security concerns.
Article Summary: Major subsea internet cable projects backed by tech giants Google and Meta Platforms are facing deployment delays in the Red Sea. The delays affect key global infrastructure intended to supply high-speed internet to Africa and Asia, throttling connectivity for these regions. The Red Sea is the historically most direct and cost-effective route for fiber-optic internet arteries.

Article Title: Google CEO Sundar Pichai celebrates new breakthrough in quantum algorithm; Elon Musk replies: ‘Looks like…’
Article Text:
What Sundar Pichai wrote in the post

“New breakthrough quantum algorithm published in @Nature today: Our Willow chip has achieved the first-ever verifiable quantum advantage.

Willow ran the algorithm - which we’ve named Quantum Echoes - 13,000x faster than the best classical algorithm on one of the world's fastest supercomputers. This new algorithm can explain interactions between atoms in a molecule using nuclear magnetic resonance, paving a path towards potential future uses in drug discovery and materials science.

And the result is verifiable, meaning its outcome can be repeated by other quantum computers or confirmed by experiments.

This breakthrough is a significant step toward the first real-world application of quantum computing, and we're excited to see where it leads.”

Why Google’s Willow chip experiment matters

Google To Invest $15 Billion On AI Hub In Visakhapatnam, CEO Sundar Pichai Speaks To PM Modi





Google CEO Sundar Pichai recently shared a post on X, formerly Twitter, announcing a new breakthrough in quantum algorithms. “Our Willow chip has achieved the first-ever verifiable quantum advantage,” Pichai wrote in the post, adding it is “13,000x faster than the best classical algorithm on one of the world's fastest supercomputers”. Pichai’s post caught the attention of Tesla CEO Elon Musk . The tech billionaire replied to Pichai’s post saying “Congrats. Looks like quantum computing is becoming relevant.”Announcing the major breakthrough, Google CEO Sundar Pichai wrote:The achievement marks a historic breakthrough in quantum computing. For the first time ever, a quantum computer has performed a complex, verifiable calculation faster than any supercomputer could — about 13,000 times faster. This moment is being called a “verifiable quantum advantage."Using Google’s Willow quantum chip, researchers ran an advanced algorithm called Quantum Echoes (or OTOC — out-of-order time correlator).This algorithm helps scientists study how information spreads in quantum systems — things like molecules, magnets, or even black holes.The key part: the result was verifiable and repeatable, meaning other quantum computers could confirm it independently.
Article Summary: Google CEO Sundar Pichai recently shared a post on X, formerly Twitter, announcing a new breakthrough in quantum algorithms. Using Google’s Willow quantum chip, researchers ran an advanced algorithm called Quantum Echoes. This algorithm helps scientists study how information spreads in quantum systems like molecules, magnets, or even black holes.

Article Title: ‘Rough news but…’: Netflix shuts down studio behind game that hit number 1 in 26 countries
Article Text:
Netflix shift in gaming strategy







Netflix has shut down the game studio Boss Fight Entertainment, the developer behind the hit mobile game Squid Game: Unleashed. The closure comes as the streaming giant pivots its strategy within its expanding video gaming unit, a report has said.The studio’s co-founder and former CEO, David Rippy, confirmed the closure in a LinkedIn post this week. He said that the studio is “very grateful for the time” it had at Netflix. Read Rippy’s full post on LinkedIn.Hi everyone – well, word has gotten around quickly about Boss Fight’s closure. Thanks, everyone who reached out today. Rough news, for sure, but I’m very grateful for the time we had at Netflix. We worked with some awesome people and made many games that I’m very proud of, including Squid Game Unleased which hit #1 in 26 countries. You’ll see lots of Boss Fighters with similar posts. Please consider them if you have any open roles – they are outstanding people and true professionals through-and-through. As for Bill, Scott and me – we’re going to take a little breather before tackling whatever is next. Love to hear from you if there’s anything interesting going on, workwise or otherwise.Another employee, David Luehmann, a director of game development at the studio, also posted on LinkedIn, saying, "After 10+ great years working at Boss Fight, the last few as part of Netflix, the time has come for the studio to close down."“I am very proud of all the people, work, and games we've released. I wish you could see what we had cooking! There are many talented people that have been impacted by this. If anyone is looking to grow, I'll have many recommendations for you!” he added.Netflix acquired Boss Fight Entertainment in 2022 as part of its effort to diversify revenue streams by building out its video game offerings, news agency Reuters reported.The studio was known for developing two games available on the platform: Netflix Stories and the highly successful Squid Game: Unleashed, which reportedly hit the number one spot in 26 countries.The streaming giant's move follows an earnings call earlier this week where Co-CEO Greg Peters specifically praised Squid Game: Unleashed as an example of the kind of narrative game the company wanted to create based on its original shows.However, the company, which named Alain Tascan as president of games last year, is implementing a new strategy that will focus on four specific categories: party, narrative, kids, and mainstream games, the report added. Article Summary: Boss Fight Entertainment's co-founder and former CEO, David Rippy, confirmed the closure in a LinkedIn post this week. The studio was known for developing two games available on the platform: Netflix Stories and the highly successful Squid Game: Unleashed. Article Title: After Japan’s second-richest man, this American billionaire sells his entire Nvidia stake worth $100 million
Article Text:
Growing wave of high-profile investor exits from Nvidia

Bubble concerns mount ahead of critical earnings report





Billionaire investor Peter Thiel has completely exited his position in Nvidia, selling approximately 537,742 shares worth nearly $100 million during the July-September period, according to regulatory filings released over the weekend. A Form 13F filing from his Thiel Macro fund showed he no longer held any Nvidia shares as of September 30.The dramatic exit comes as concerns mount over an AI-fueled bubble in technology valuations. Thiel, who co-founded PayPal and Palantir, had earlier this year warned about stretched valuations in Nvidia and compared the recent spike in tech valuations to the 1999-2000 Dotcom bubble crash.The Nvidia holdings accounted for nearly 40% of Thiel's portfolio, and their sale shrunk his fund's equity book by almost two-thirds. His Los Angeles-based hedge fund held $212 million in long U.S. stocks in Q2, which plummeted to approximately $74.4 million in Q3. The rationale behind Thiel's sale was not immediately clear, though his previous warnings about AI valuations suggest growing concerns about market sustainability.Thiel's move follows a troubling pattern among prominent investors. Japanese tech conglomerate SoftBank disclosed it had sold off its entire Nvidia stake just a week earlier.Additionally, investor Michael Burry, famous for predicting the 2008 financial crisis, recently disclosed heavy short positions on Nvidia and Palantir Technologies.Beyond dumping Nvidia entirely, Thiel also slashed his Tesla holdings from 272,613 shares to just 65,000 shares and completely exited his 208,747-share position in energy generation firm Vistra Energy. However, he purchased 79,181 shares in Apple and 49,000 shares in Microsoft during the same period.The timing is particularly significant as Nvidia prepares to report earnings Wednesday afternoon, with options positioning extremely bullish and the market pricing in about a 7% post-earnings move. Investors have grown increasingly concerned about how AI leader OpenAI plans to meet its over $1 trillion spending commitments and how this could affect Nvidia and other chipmakers. Nvidia's investment in OpenAI has also sparked concerns over circular financing among analysts.
Article Summary: Billionaire investor Peter Thiel has completely exited his position in Nvidia, selling approximately 537,742 shares worth nearly $100 million during the July- September period. The dramatic exit comes as concerns mount over an AI-fueled bubble in technology valuations. Japanese tech conglomerate SoftBank disclosed it had sold off its entire Nvidia stake just a week earlier.

A British man has been convicted of hacking Twitter accounts belonging to high-profile figures, including former US President Barack Obama . Britain's Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) announced that it has obtained a civil recovery order to seize 42 Bitcoin and other crypto assets linked to the scam. The attack involved using the hijacked accounts to steal digital currency from followers and threaten celebrities. O’Connor pleaded guilty in the US to charges including computer intrusion, wire fraud and extortion. He has been serving a five-year sentence in a US prison since 2023, the report claims.O'Connor was initially arrested in Spain in 2021. He was then extradited after the Spanish High Court determined that the US was the appropriate jurisdiction for prosecution, given the location of the evidence and the victims, the Reuters report added.The July 2020 attack affected accounts belonging to then–Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden, Tesla CEO Elon Musk, former US President Obama and others, including Bill Gates, Warren Buffett, and Kim Kardashian. As a result, Twitter (now known as X) temporarily restricted activity on verified accounts.In a statement to Reuters, prosecutor Adrian Foster said:The order issued last week builds on a previous property-freezing ruling made during extradition proceedings.UK prosecutors said a court-appointed trustee will now liquidate the assets.The group responsible for the 2020 breach used SIM-swapping and social engineering to access internal Twitter systems. They then posted false messages encouraging followers to send Bitcoin to wallets controlled by the attackers, collecting over $100,000 within a few hours.UK prosecutors have secured an order to seize crypto assets worth about £4.11 million, including Bitcoin, Ethereum and stablecoins. The action is part of civil proceeds-of-crime rules that allow authorities to recover illegal earnings from cases prosecuted outside the UK.However, O'Connor’s actions were not limited to the Bitcoin scheme. Court filings show he and others accessed private messages, extorted victims, and sent threats to public figures using compromised Twitter administrative tools. His guilty plea covered the Twitter breach as well as a wider set of SIM-swap offences and crypto-related theft.O'Connor, known online aswas extradited from Spain in 2023 after a long legal process and agreed to a plea deal with US prosecutors. His sentence required him to forfeit $794,000 and pay restitution, while the UK order seeks further assets believed to be linked to the offences and accessible under British jurisdiction.The CPS highlighted the case as part of its broader asset-recovery work, noting that nearly £478 million has been recovered through confiscation and compensation orders over the past five years, with more than £95 million returned to victims. For O’Connor, the ruling means that even while serving his sentence in the US, more of his illegal gains will be removed.

Joseph James O'Connor ordered to repay $5.40 million (4.1 million pounds) worth of Bitcoin for the same. UK's Crown Prosecution Service announced that it has obtained a civil recovery order to seize 42 Bitcoin and other crypto assets linked to the scam.

According to Bezos, invention, not repetitive execution, is going to be the anchor of human relevance in tomorrow’s workforce.During his appearance, Bezos made a clear distinction: the workers who will never be replaced by AI are those who can invent people who generate original ideas rather than just carry out tasks. He described this as the foundation of technological progress, noting that invention drives innovation and change more than routine work ever could.Bezos reinforced this with his own example: “Put me in front of a whiteboard and I can generate a hundred ideas in half an hour.”The founder of Amazon highlighted how AI is already reshaping the labour market, particularly in his own company. As automation expands within Amazon, many roles that depend on repetitive or data-driven tasks are increasingly handled by machines.He warned that only a fraction of employees will be truly insulated from displacement, those who invent rather than just execute.This mirrors broader trends across companies: AI systems are being deployed for logistics, customer service, data processing, and other operational roles, reducing the need for human labour in those areas.Bezos explained that when he interviews prospective employees, he specifically asks whether they’ve invented something, not necessarily a patentable invention, but any new process, metric, or system. He believes this mindset identifies individuals who are creative problem solvers, not just task performers.He has repeatedly said that those who don’t have a pioneering or experimental mindset are unlikely to thrive long term, especially in an AI-first era.Bezos’s remarks come at a time when many companies are rapidly scaling up AI adoption, and fears about job displacement are growing. For workers, this means that developing creativity and innovation skills may become essential for long-term employability. Hiring practices, too, may shift: companies might prioritise inventiveness over past experience or technical skill.Educational institutions and training programs may also need to adjust, promoting more creative thinking, problem-finding, and entrepreneurial mindsets rather than purely technical proficiency.
Article Summary: Jeff Bezos: This skill will keep humans irreplaceable in an AI world. Workers who focus on invention, not just execution, may be more resilient in their careers, because inventors are less likely to be replaced by machines. Bezos: Invention, not repetitive execution, is going to be the anchor of human relevance.

Article Title: Anand Mahindra points to the 'Big crisis' that Ford CEO said is needed to keep America running
Article Text:
Here’s what Anand Mahindra wrote in the post

We’re so busy fearing AI will wipe out white-collar jobs that we’re missing a far bigger crisis: the scarcity of skilled trades.

Ford CEO @jimfarley98 made a startling revelation in a recent podcast: Ford has 5,000 mechanic jobs unfilled, many paying $120,000 a year, and still no takers. Across the U.S., over a million essential roles in plumbing, electrical work, trucking and factory operations lie vacant.

This isn’t the future.

It’s happening now.

For decades, we pushed degrees and desk jobs to the top of the “aspirational” ladder and quietly pushed skilled trades to the bottom. Yet these are the jobs AI cannot replace: they require judgment, dexterity, apprenticeship, and real-world expertise.

So the real question is: Are we about to witness a reset in what society considers a dream career?

Because if this trend continues, the biggest winners of the AI era will be the people who can actually build, fix, and keep the world running.

Marx imagined workers rising through struggle.

He never imagined they’d rise because they became too skilled, too scarce, and too essential to replace!

A revolution not through violence… but through value-discovery

Article Title: Why death of a cat has 'shaken' San Francisco and is troubling Google's car service Waymo
Article Text:

The death of a neighborhood cat named Kit Kat in a collision with a Waymo robotaxi has ignited outrage in San Francisco, leaving the residents ‘shaken’ while also transforming a tragedy into a debate over autonomous vehicles. Article Title: How subsidiary of a blacklisted Chinese company 'fooled' America to get banned Nvidia chips into China
Article Text:
President and CEO of Nvidia Corporation Jensen Huang delivers a speech during the Computex 2025 exhibition in Taipei, Taiwan. (AP Photo/Chiang Ying-ying, File)

Four-step workaround exploits regulatory loopholes

Nvidia H20 Chips for China: What’s Really Going On?

Nvidia's China market share collapses from 95% to zero

Trump administration won't enforce Biden-era restrictions





China is getting access to Nvidia chips, or rather Nvidia chips whose sale is prohibited in the country. Inside a windowless building in Jakarta, Indonesia, approximately 2,300 of Nvidia's cutting-edge Blackwell chips are being prepared for use by a Chinese AI company—despite President Donald Trump's explicit opposition to selling such technology to China. The complex transaction involved multiple countries and entities, yet appears to violate no US laws. A Wall Street Journal investigation has revealed how Chinese companies are accessing Nvidia's most advanced AI chips despite US export restrictions, exposing significant gaps in America's technology control strategy.The chips reached their destination through a carefully orchestrated chain. Nvidia first sold semiconductors to Aivres, a Silicon Valley-based company whose parent is one-third owned by Inspur—a Chinese tech firm blacklisted by the US government in 2023 for working on military supercomputing. However, current regulations don't restrict Nvidia from selling to American subsidiaries like Aivres.Aivres then brokered a $100 million deal with Indosat Ooredoo Hutchison, an Indonesian telecom provider, selling 32 server racks containing 72 Blackwell chips each. The arrangement was finalized only after securing Shanghai-based AI startup INF Tech as the end customer, according to people familiar with the matter cited by the WSJ.The Jakarta case highlights the effectiveness—and limitations—of US export controls. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang told reporters in November there were "no active discussions" about selling Blackwell chips to China, stating: "Currently, we are not planning to ship anything to China."Yet Huang has repeatedly criticized the policy's impact on American business. Speaking at a Citadel Securities event in October, he revealed Nvidia went from 95% market share in China to zero, adding: "I can't imagine any policymaker thinking that that's a good idea." He described China as potentially a $50 billion market this year, growing to hundreds of billions by decade's end.The case has alarmed current and former US national-security officials who fear Chinese companies could eventually redirect commercial AI capabilities toward military applications through Beijing's civil-military fusion strategy. In its final days, the Biden administration introduced rules requiring closer scrutiny of advanced chip sales to countries like Indonesia, but the Trump administration declined to enforce them.INF Tech, founded by Chinese-born American MIT graduate Qi Yuan, insists it conducts no military research and complies fully with US regulations. The company plans to use the computing power for AI applications in finance and healthcare.As the US-China technological rivalry intensifies, the Jakarta deal demonstrates how legal workarounds and third-country intermediaries can circumvent even stringent export controls.
Article Summary: Chinese companies are accessing Nvidia's most advanced AI chips despite US export restrictions. Deal exposed significant gaps in America's technology control strategy. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang said in November there were "no active discussions" about selling chips to China. In October, he revealed Nvidia went from 95% market share in China to zero.

Article Title: India’s first full-fledged privacy law goes live: What DPDP Rules 2025 mean for your daily apps
Article Text:

What DPDP Rules 2025 mean for WhatsApp, Facebook, Instagram and other apps

What DPDP 2025 rules say on protection of children's personal data

DPDP 2025 rules to companies: You cannot transfer this data outside India





The Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MeitY) recently notified the Digital Personal Data Protection (DPDP) rules 2025. The new rules mark the full operationalisation of the Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023 – India’s first comprehensive data law. Enacted by Parliament on 11 August 2023, the DPDP Act establishes a comprehensive framework for protecting digital personal data, setting out the obligations of entities handling such data and the rights and duties of individuals.The DPDP Rules 2025 provide a consent-based system in order to protect personal data of people using social media platforms like Facebook, Instagram, or shopping apps like Amazon, Flipkart or using online banking, digital payments and online government services. The aim is to ensure that the users know how their data is used and they have more control over their data. Under the rules, platforms and companies found violating the rules will face penalties, including up to Rs 250cr for serious failures to protect data, and breaches. Here’s a breakdown of what the new rules mean for platforms like Meta, Google and others that are widely used on a day-to-day basis.But before proceeding, it is important to under two important entities frequently used in the rules – Data Fiduciary and Data Principals.A Data Principal is the individual to whom the personal data belongs, or the person whose information is being collected or processed. In layman's terms, a data principal stands for a general user. While a Data Fiduciary is the entity — such as a company, organisation or individual — that determines why the data is being processed and how that processing will be carried out.The DPDP Rules 2025 outlines 'Reasonable safety guards’ for social media companies such as Facebook and Instagram and other online platforms to protect personal data in their possession or under their control. At the same time, these companies and organisations must put stricter checks in place for young users, including getting a parent’s verified approval before letting anyone under 18 join.Platforms are required to safeguard users’ personal data through “encryption, obfuscation, masking or the use of virtual tokens mapped to that personal data”. These tools make the data unreadable to anyone who shouldn’t see it. Even if someone gets access, the information stays protected.Further, companies need to track who accesses the stored data. The rules require online platforms to keep an activity log of every time someone views or uses personal data. In order to allow proper investigation of unauthorized access, organisations must keep logs and relevant personal data for one year. They can also store it for a longer or shorter time, but only if another law requires it.In case the Data Fiduciary hires a Data Processor to handle the data, the contract must clearly state that they also have to follow strong security practices. The law also requires companies to establish a Data Protection Board that will function as a fully digital institution, enabling citizens to file and track complaints online through a dedicated platform and mobile app. “Appeals against its decisions will lie with the Appellate Tribunal, TDSAT. ”Under the new rules, companies found in violation of these rules will face a penalty of up to Rs 25 crore. The government has given a window of 18-months for the online platforms to transition and comply with the new rules.Under the DPDP Rules 2025, a company must delete a user’s personal data after a period of three years of inactivity – unless the individual has a more recent interaction or the data is legally required to be retained or “its retention is necessary for compliance with any law.”Before deleting the data, the company (Data Fiduciary) must give the person (Data Principal) a 48-hour warning. The message must clearly state that their data will be deleted soon, unless they log into their account or contact the company. If they still need the service or want to use any of their rights related to their data, they should take action before the deadline.“At least forty-eight hours before completion of the time period for erasure of personal data under this rule, the Data Fiduciary shall inform the Data Principal that such personal data shall be erased upon completion of such period, unless she logs into her user account or otherwise initiates contact with the Data Fiduciary for the performance of the specified purpose or exercises her rights in relation to the processing of such personal data,” the rules read.The DPDP Rules 2025 requires online platforms to quickly inform users in case of any personal data breach. “On becoming aware of any personal data breach, the Data Fiduciary shall, to the best of its knowledge, intimate to each affected Data Principal, in a concise, clear and plain manner and without delay, through her user account or any mode of communication registered by her with the Data Fiduciary,” the rule states.The intimation can be done through-Regarding safety and protection of online children data, the new law mandates online platforms to obtain verifiable consent of the parent “before the processing of any personal data of a child”. Further, is is now required to “observe due diligence, for checking that the individual identifying herself as the parent is an adult who is identifiable if required in connection with compliance with any law for the time being in force in India”.For persons with disabilities who cannot make legal decisions even with support, consent must come from a lawful guardian verified under applicable laws, the rules say.Additionally, the new rules also let the government block certain types of data from being sent outside India. According to experts, this may create challenges for big tech companies like Meta, Google, and Amazon, which depend heavily on global data flows.To give people more control over their online information, the law allows every user to see, correct, update, or delete their personal data whenever they want. Users can even appoint someone else to manage these rights for them if needed. Companies handling this data must respond to such requests within 90 days.The organisations must display clear contact information—such as that of a designated officer or Data Protection Officer—to help individuals raise queries about personal data processing. Significant Data Fiduciaries have enhanced obligations including independent audits, impact assessments and stronger due diligence for deployed technologies. They must also comply with government-specified restrictions on certain categories of data, including localisation where required.
Article Summary: The DPDP Rules 2025 provide a consent-based system to protect personal data of people using social media platforms like Facebook, Instagram, or using online banking, digital payments and online government services. Under the rules, platforms and companies found violating the rules will face penalties, including up to Rs 250cr.

Article Title: Apple may do with iPhone 18 series what the company has never done in the last 15 years
Article Text:
Image Credit: Apple Newsroom

Apple's Secret 3-Year Plan: A New iPhone Era is Coming!

Why is Apple moving away from September-only iPhone launches

iPhone Air was never meant to be annual





Apple is seemingly abandoning its famous fall-only iPhone launch strategy, spreading new models across the entire year in what marks the biggest shift in the iPhone’s release history since 2011. Starting in fall 2026, Apple will unveil three premium models—the iPhone 18 Pro, iPhone 18 Pro Max, and its first foldable iPhone—according to Bloomberg's Mark Gurman in his Power On newsletter. Six months later, in spring 2027, the company plans to release the base iPhone 18, iPhone 18e, and potentially a second-generation iPhone Air.The move ends over a decade of September spectacles that concentrated Apple's biggest revenue driver into a single season. Gurman reports this pattern will continue "for years to come," with Apple launching between five and six new iPhone models annually instead of the traditional four released simultaneously.The twice-yearly schedule aims to distribute revenue more evenly throughout the year while reducing pressure on Apple's engineering teams and manufacturing partners. The strategy also prevents premium and budget models from competing for attention during the same marketing window.Bloomberg notes the shift gives Apple multiple opportunities to counter competitors like Samsung, which has long spread Galaxy and foldable launches across different seasons. The troubled 2024 rollout of Apple Intelligence highlighted how cramming too many products into fall was taking its toll.Contrary to recent reports suggesting Apple delayed the iPhone Air 2 due to poor sales, Gurman clarifies the device was never scheduled for annual updates. The absence of "17" in its name—simply called "iPhone Air"—signaled Apple's intention to update it on a flexible timeline, similar to the iPhone SE.The next iPhone Air will focus on adopting a 2-nanometer chip for improved battery life rather than structural changes, according to the Power On newsletter. While adding a second camera is "technically possible," Gurman considers it unlikely given the device's already crowded design and modest sales performance.The spring releases will also bring major smart home devices, the iPhone 17e, updated Macs, and refreshed iPads, giving Apple consistent product momentum throughout the year.
Article Summary: Apple is moving away from September-only iPhone launches. Starting in fall 2026, Apple will unveil three premium models. Six months later, in spring 2027, the company plans to release the base iPhone 18, iPhone 18e, and potentially a second-generation iPhone Air.
